III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149 Resident nutrition.
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible
Description meals daily unless medically contraindicated and
documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are served food that is raw and unhealthy.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed over video conference on
06/06/2023 and no additional information for this allegation was
provided.
An unannounced face-to-face visit was made to the facility to
initiate the investigation on 05/24/2023. Supervisor 1 was
interviewed at that time. She was familiar with the allegations
made and confirmed that there had never been any formal
grievances filed by Youth A or any other youth in the last few
months regarding food or drink at the facility.
Cook 1 was interviewed on 05/27/2023 during this unannounced
face-to-face visit at the facility. He stated that he has heard
complaints about food cooked at the facility in the past but always
clarifies if it is about unsafe or inedible food, or personal
preferences. Cook 1 stated that he has not been told that any
food he has cooked has been unsafe to eat and described safety
precautions he takes in order to prevent that from occurring. Cook
1 stated that, because of this exact type of concern, most of the
food items that they serve the youth are pre-cooked and frozen.
During this interview Cook 1 was not able to locate a food
thermometer. He stated that he normally has it on his person
while cooking but did not that day and did not offer a specific
reason as to why.
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E and Youth F were
interviewed on 05/24/2023 separately during this unannounced
face-to-face visit to the facility. All five youths offered similar
accounts to what why have experienced for food and drink at the
facility. Youth C stated that there had been one time where the
dough on pigs-in-a-blanket had looked a little raw but he didn't
know if that was unsanitary, and he chose to not eat that item.
Youth C stated there was also one time when the chicken that
was served looked a little too pink, as did Youth E. Youth C
stated that he has seen milk past the expiration date by a day or
two in the milk refrigerator, but that was then put in a separate
location and he had non-expired milk to drink. Youth D had the
2

same to share about the milk as well. All five youths stated that
there were alternative food items, namely peanut butter and jelly
sandwiches, available for all meals if they did not want to eat what
was provided. When asked about their ability to point out anything
of concern about the food to staff, all the youth stated that they felt
like they could without repercussions and none of them had filed
any grievances about the food.
DHHS Worker 1 shared that she was able to view lunch that was
served to youth during an unannounced face-to-face visit at the
facility on 05/31/2023 and she noted no concerns.
Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face
visit to the hospital where he had been admitted on 06/06/2023.
When asked to elaborate about concerns about the food, Youth A
had similar concerns to share as other youth interviewed. He
stated that his main concern was that most of the food that they
were fed at the placement came from frozen or packaged items.
He also noted that many items felt undercooked or overcooked
and there was not consistency. Youth A stated that he had been
served chicken that he felt was undercooked on more than one
occasion, as an example. Youth A also stated that there was a
time when he noticed the milk refrigerator smelled like it had
spoiled and it was found that some milk had broken out of the
cartons inside it overnight. Youth A believed that this was cleaned
that day but was not sure. Youth A stated that there were always
alternatives available for any meals, but that most of the time it
was only a prepackaged peanut butter and jelly. Youth A stated
that he was not sure if he had ever spoken to the cooks or any
staff about this issue and confirmed that he had not filed any
grievances regarding it.
Cook 2 was interviewed during an unannounced face-to-face visit
at the facility on 06/20/2023. He confirmed that he was the other
cook that works in the kitchen and had worked with this program
and other programs within the organization for years. Cook 2
stated that there are few items that they cook that are not pre-
cooked, like chicken legs or stew meat. He provided a tour of the
freezer and showed several other options that were listed on the
upcoming menu that were already pre-cooked and delivered
frozen. Cook 2 provided a list of temperatures that each type of
meat needs to be cooked to in order for it to be safe and edible.
He stated that there is always a chance that something is not
cooked correctly, but in the last few years of working for the
organization he did not believe he had produced anything unsafe
to eat and he had not heard from any youth or other staff that was
3

the case. It was noted that during this interview Cook 2 appeared
to be following several strict health practices, such as changing
rubber gloves in between handling any individual foods, asking for
anyone entering the kitchen to wear a hairnet and producing a
meat thermometer that was used several times to check food
items being cooked at the time.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed during an unannounced face-to-
face visit at the facility on 06/20/2023. She confirmed she was the
supervisor of both Cook 1 and Cook 2 and managed ordering and
inventory of food items, health inspections and training as well as
grievances. Supervisor 1 confirmed that she had not received any
grievances from any youth regarding food. She stated that all the
staff are ServSafe certified and has worked closely with the local
health department during inspections with no concerns presented
to her.
A separate refrigerator is located in the facility’s dining area used
to hold milk cartons for the youth. This was checked on
05/24/2023, 06/13/2023 and 06/30/2023 during unannounced
visits to the facility and on all of those occasions there were no
expired milk cartons available to youth and the refrigerator
appeared to be clean.
Documentation reviewed:
• Supervisor 1’s ServSafe Certification dated 04/19/2022 with
a dated of expiration of 04/19/2027 was provided. It was
noted that Cook 1 and Cook 2 do not participate in the
ServSafe Food Protection Manager Certification
Examination because they work under Supervisor 1.
• State Food Safety Certificate of Completion for Supervisor
1 dated 11/24/2021 (valid for five years) was provided.
• Grievance log documentation does not show any
grievances filed for food or beverage related issues during
2023.
• Reviewed Environmental Health Inspection completed on
June 26, 2023 which provided an A rating for compliance
with rules.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews and documentation reviewed it
was not found that there was sufficient evidence to support a rule
violation regarding the safety of the food at the facility.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDED:
It was discussed with the Chief Administrator that anyone working
in the kitchen should be required to follow all necessary protocols
regarding food safety.
4

Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It was alleged that staff are not aware of youth's behaviors and as
a result Youth A was hurt in an incident with another youth.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face
visit to the hospital where he had been admitted on 06/06/2023.
During this interview Youth A stated that he had gotten into an
argument with Youth G recently but could not exactly recall when.
During this incident Youth A stated that Youth G tried to “come at
him” with a sock and a brush. Youth A stated that when this
occurred a staff member intervened and there was no physical
contact made with Youth A by Youth G. Youth A stated that he
believed it was staff’s responsibility to intervene sooner in the
interaction to prevent it from escalating to that point. He believed
that this occurred because staff did not pay enough attention to
the youth, and that he had seen staff members looking at their
phones and wearing individual headphones at times while
working. Youth A stated that he could not recall any specific staff
members that he had seen on their phones or with individual
headphones in their ears while working.
Youth A was also asked to recount the interactions during the
incident where he had experienced injuries to his wrist and had
stated that this was a result of facility staff not doing their jobs.
Youth A stated that he had AWOL’ed from the facility one day and
had made it off of the facility grounds and started to make his way
in to the local town on foot. At some point he encountered law
enforcement and he stated that he began to fight them when they
attempted to interact with him. Youth A stated that handcuffs
were used and that he experienced bruising and pain on his wrists
as a result. Youth A stated that the handcuffs were taken off of
him by law enforcement upon his return to the facility. He
confirmed that no facility staff were involved in this part of the
incident and that he received medical attention for his wrists at
that point in time when he returned to the facility.
Youth G was interviewed during an unannounced face-to-face
visit at the facility on 06/13/2023. He stated that he recalled the
incident in question. Youth G recalled being angry at Youth A for
something that was said to him and that Youth A was spitting and
dumping water on Youth G. Youth G admitted to attempting to hit
5

Youth A, but doing so very quickly because he knew staff would
try to stop him. Youth G stated that a male staff was able to
intervene quickly and that the incident ended that fast.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 07/18/2023. She
confirmed that she was the staff member involved in this
altercation and intervened between Youth A and Youth G. Staff 3
stated that she successfully de-escalated the incident in question
and that no other staff were immediately involved. She recalled
being in the unit with Youth A and Youth G among other youth and
seeing Youth G escalate quickly by coming up behind Youth A
and hitting him. Staff 3 stated that this part of the interaction only
lasted seconds before she was able to step in between the two
youth. She recalled that Youth G immediately stopped attempting
to hit Youth A once she was in his way. Staff 3 stated that she did
not have to put her hands on Youth G for the incident to end.
Documents reviewed:
• An Incident Report dated 05/20/2023 involving Youth A and
Youth G was provided and reviewed. This described the
incident in question and provided a similar course of events
as both Youth A, Youth G and Staff 3.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews with youth and staff and
documentation reviewed there was no evidence found that any
staff failed to act quickly enough in response to escalating
behaviors of the youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Discipline
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not
limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a
youth’s background or appearance or mental state. Yelling,
threats, ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation While admitted to the hospital, Youth A alleged that Staff 2
verbally assaulted him.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face
visit to the hospital where he had been admitted on 06/06/2023.
While discussing other allegations, Youth A alleged that he had
been mistreated by Staff 2 recently while admitted to the hospital.
6

Youth A stated that Staff 2 was providing supervision for him while
he was admitted to the hospital and still technically placed with the
facility. While doing so, Youth A and Staff 2 got into a
disagreement about how to have the door to his room. Youth A
stated that he wanted his door propped open with a chair, and
admitted that hospital staff had instructed him not to do so. Youth
A stated that Staff 2 was trying to instruct him not to prop the door
open to his room, and in doing so Staff 2 allegedly told Youth A
that she “did not give a fuck” about what he wanted. Youth A
stated that he told her in response “How would you feel if you got
fired.”
Staff 2 was interviewed during an unannounced face-to-face visit
at the facility on 06/13/2023. She stated that she was involved
with Youth A in providing supervisory shifts while he had been
recently admitted to the hospital. She provided details on what
occurred from her recollection. Staff 2 stated that a hospital
staffer had informed her that Youth A had closed his door several
times and tried tying something to his bed to prevent others from
entering his room and out of safety they needed is door to be fully
open at all times. Staff 2 stated that Youth A began to become
agitated upon her arrival because he wanted to go for a walk and
had been previously told by hospital staff that he could not
because he was a flight risk. Staff 2 stated that he eventually was
able to call his foster care worker to speak with her, and while
doing so he tried to prop his door open with a chair. As Staff 2
told him he could not do this Youth A got more agitated and stated
to her “You must not care about losing your job” and “I’m going to
say that you told me to shut the fuck up.” Staff 2 stated that she
was able to not become escalated by these comments and Youth
A eventually de-escalated on his own.
DHHS Foster Care Worker was interviewed over the phone on
07/18/2023. She stated that she did not specifically recall being
on the phone during the incident in question but that she did have
multiple phone calls with Youth A during his time in the hospital
after his placement at the facility was disrupted. She stated that
this incident may have occurred when she was on the phone with
Youth A and she heard Youth A trying to argue with a facility staff
member that was at the hospital with him. DHHS Foster Care
Worker stated that she heard Youth A state “Hold on a minute” to
her and then hung up the phone. She confirmed that she never
heard from Youth A any allegations or information about this
specific incident, and also noted that she has been involved in
mistruths from Youth A about placement staff in the past. DHHS
Foster Care Worker stated that Youth A was frequently upset
7

during that time because he wanted to be able to leave the
hospital and was not allowed to at the time because of safety
concerns.
Analysis Through face-to-face interviews there was not sufficient evidence
to prove that Youth A was verbally assaulted by Staff 2.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
